section.title: About this document
section.para: This is the official &MiKTeX; &FAQ;. It is available in the following formats:

listitem.para: formatted in HTML entirely on one web page
formatted in HTML with one web page per section

question.para: What is &MiKTeX;?

answer.para: &MiKTeX; is a complete &TeX; system for Windows.

question.para: Is there a home page?

answer.para: Yes. The official project page is http://www.miktex.org.

question.para: Which &Windows; version is required for running &MiKTeX;?

answer.para: &MiKTeX; requires one of the following &Windows; operating systems:

question.para: Am I allowed to redistribute &MiKTeX;?

answer.para: The &MiKTeX; distribution is a conglomerate of many software packages. To the best of my knowledge, all packages meet the requirements of the Debian Free Software Guidelines. This means that &MiKTeX; may be freely used, copied, modified, and redistributed.
Please visit this page, for more information

question.para: How do I download &MiKTeX;?

answer.para: It is recommended that you download the &BasicMiKTeXInstaller;. This allows you set up a basic &MiKTeX; system (see ).
Download the &MiKTeXNetInstaller;, if you want to set up a complete &MiKTeX; system (see ).

question.para: How do I install &MiKTeX;?

answer.para: You use one of the installers to set up a a &MiKTeX; system:

listitem.para: The Basic &MiKTeX; installer can be used to set up a basic &MiKTeX; system.
The &MiKTeXNetInstaller; can be used to set up a complete &MiKTeX; system.

answer.para: For more information, read the section Installing &MiKTeX; in the &MiKTeX; manual.

question.para: What is the Basic &MiKTeX; installer?

answer.para: The &BasicMiKTeXInstaller; sets up a basic &MiKTeX; system. Additional packages can be installed on-the-fly. This has the advantage of keeping a minimal &MiKTeX; system.

question.para: What is the &MiKTeXNetInstaller;?

answer.para: This installer serves two purposes:

listitem.para: It downloads all available package archive files to your computer.

question.para: Is &MiKTeX; available on &CD; or &DVD;?

answer.para: Yes, &MiKTeX; is available on &CDRDVDdashR; (see this page).

The &CDRDVDdashR; contains a live &MiKTeX; system, which makes it possible to run &MiKTeX; directly from the &CDRDVDdashR;. Alternatively, the &CDRDVDdashR; allows you to install &MiKTeX; on your hard-disk.

question.para: Is it possible to download &MiKTeX; without the wizard?

answer.para: You can use your favorite download tool to get the contents of the &CTAN; directory systems/win32/miktex.

question.para: How do I get support?

answer.para: Please visit , for an overview of available support options.

question.para: Is there a mailing list?

answer.para: Yes.

question.para: How can I join the mailing list?

answer.para: To join the list, direct your browser to the MiKTeX-Users Info Page and fill out the form.
You will receive instructions (via email) on how to use the mailing list.

question.para: How can I read old articles?

answer.para: To see the collection of prior postings to the MiKTeX-Users list, visit the MiKTeX-Users Archives.

question.para: How can I leave the mailing list?

answer.para: Visit the MiKTeX-Users Info Page and enter you subscription email address to change your subscription status.

question.para: I have installed &MiKTeX;. How do I use it?

answer.para: If you have never used &TeX; before: we recommend that, first of all, you work through a &TeX;/&LaTeX; tutorial. A good starting point is this page.
&MiKTeX; doesn't differ very much from any other &TeX; system you might have used before. Typesetting with &MiKTeX; involves these steps:

step.para: Edit the &LaTeX; source with your favourite text editor.
Compile the &LaTeX; source into a &DVI; file, i.e., say something like latex MyMastersThesis.
Open the result by double-clicking the &DVI; file (e.g., MyMastersThesis.dvi) in Windows Explorer.

answer.para: You usually use a &LaTeX; editor to carry out these steps (see ).

question.para: Which program should I use to edit &LaTeX; documents?

answer.para: Links to recommendable freeware &TeX; shells (editors) can be found on this page.

question.para: How do I update my &MiKTeX; system?

answer.para: You use &MiKTeXUpdateWizard; (StartMiKTeXMiKTeX Update Wizard) to update installed packages. For more information, read the section Installing Updates in the &MiKTeX; manual.

question.para: Which is the best directory to keep .sty files where &MiKTeX; can find them?

answer.para: &MiKTeXPackageManager; takes care of the proper installation of well known &LaTeX; packages.
If (for some reason) you have to install a package by hand, then you should copy the input files into the directory tex\latex\misc relative to a registered root directory. For example:

step.para: Create the root directory C:\Local TeX Files.
Create the sub-directory tex\latex\misc and copy your input files (*.sty, *.cls) here.
Register the root directory (C:\Local TeX Files) in &MiKTeXOptions;.

answer.para: For more information, read the section Integrating Local Additions in the &MiKTeX; manual.

question.para: How do I add new languages to the &LaTeX; format file?

answer.para: You use &MiKTeXOptions; to add new languages. For more information, read the section Selecting Hyphenation Tables in the &MiKTeX; manual.

question.para: How do I install package X?

answer.para: If package X is a part of the &MiKTeX; package repository, then you install it with the help of &MiKTeXPackageManager;. See the section Working With the Package Manager in the &MiKTeX; manual.

For the impatient: try it with
mpm --verbose --install X
If the package turns out to be missing in the &MiKTeX; package repository, then you must install it manually. See also .

question.para: Why is package X not &MiKTeX; package repository?

answer.para: There are two possible reasons:

listitem.para: It is a new package of which the &MiKTeX; maintainers are not aware of.
The package's license doesn't meet the requirements of the Debian Free Software Guidelines.

question.para: How can I find out which package the file x.y belongs to?

answer.para: The search facility in &MiKTeXPackageManager; allows you to enter all or part of a file name. For example, enter colortbl.* to find out that colortbl.sty belongs to the package carlisle.

question.para: How can I change the output file name?

answer.para:
You can use option --job-name
--job-name
to set the name of the output file.

For example, you would run
pdflatex --job-name=dog cat.tex
to create the &PDF; file dog.pdf instead of cat.pdf.

question.para: How can I change the output directory?

answer.para:
You can use the option --output-directory
--output-directory
Output files
Output files secifying location for
to specify an alternative location for all output files.

For example, you would run
pdflatex --output-directory=C:\temp mydoc.tex
to deposit the output file (mydoc.pdf) in C:\temp\.

question.para: How do I insert source specials into the &DVI; file?

answer.para:
You use the --src-specials

question.para: How can I navigate to a random page?

answer.para: You can type the page number followed by g to jump to a certain page. For example, typing the key sequence 220g will direct Yap to page 220.

question.para: I want to see what's going on backstage. Where does &MiKTeX; write the trace messages?

answer.para: &MiKTeX; programs log their actions into the &DebugView; window, if you specify suitable trace options.

question.para: How do I use the &DebugView; window?

answer.para: First of all, you will need the &DebugView; utility. To download &DebugView;, visit the &DebugView; page and follow the download/installation instructions.

question.para: How do I set trace options?

answer.para: Set the environment variable MIKTEX_TRACE. The value must be a comma-separated list of trace stream names. For example,
will trace all errors and file accesses. For more information, read the section Trace Streams in the &MiKTeX; manual.
